Journal Story: Its hot in Florida this summer, I am so looking forward to a hike in the Blue Ridge Mountain on the AT in September. I have been going to the gym 3 times week. And I have been cycling when possible to build up my endurance.
I survived Hurricane Irma,so now its time to go hiking. Plan to start in Waynesboro, Va on Thursday, Sept 21,2017.
I'm all set. Keeping an eye on Hurricane Marie. Hopefully it will stay away from Florida and let me enjoy the trail.

My sister Anne dropped me off at Waynesboro and I was hiking my 8 am. I had flown into Charlottesville Airport and she shuttled me to the trailhead. Waynesboro is about 45 minutes from Charlottesville, so it is a good jumping off point. First day hike was moderate with no big climbs. The weather is dry and in the dry 70's.

Hiked from Calf MountainShelter to Turk Gap, only 4.4 miles. The hills were killing me and I decided to hitch a ride to Loft Mountain Campsite. It was 10 miles from Turk Gap to the next shelter and I didn't want to risk getting stuck on the trail exhausted. At Loft Mountain, I rested up and got ready for some more hill climbs.

A good day of moderate climbs. I saw a bear at Ivy Creek. He ran away as soon as he saw me. I have also seen several deer and lots of south bound (Sobo) hikers. They started in Maine in June and aim to finish the trail in Georgia before Thanksgiving. Overall the trail is dry, many creeks and streams are dry. At this shelter, a very weak spring was barely flowing. What a difference from 2013 when it rained every day in SNP for 2 weeks.

3 major climbs, I just need to pace myself. This hut had a great pipe spring. And good campsites. Met my first yo-yo. That's a hiker who hiked from Georgia to Maine then turned around to hike back to Georgia. Wow!  Makes me feel like a slacker.

I hiked from 7:30 to 3. Over Hightop Mountain and Baldface Mountain. I am a slow climber but pick up speed elsewhere. This campsite is run by the National Park Service. With my senior pass, it costs only $7.50 and includes flushing toilets, running water, a campsite with hot showers and a laundry room. A great deal. Talked around a campfire with a hiker, Backdraft, a a couple from Wisconsin. A great evening. Dry & cool. As I was hiking I found a pair of glasses on the trail. They belong to a group of three lady hikers I met the previous day. I carried them to the camp site and luckily found the group before they lift the camp site.  The trail provides!
Hiked over Hazeltop Mountain, the highest mountain on the AT in SNP at 3812 feet. Hiked OK until the last climb to the lodge. Having a good dinner tonight and sleep in a bed.  Heaven!

Got up early and had a great breakfast at the lodge, then I hit the trail, around 8:15. By 1:30, I was at Skyland Lodge and refueled with a cheeseburger & lots of ice water & Ice tea. I hiked over Hawksbill Mountain (3640'), Stoney Man Mountain (3837') and the Pinnacle (3730'). We got to the hut at 6:30, just as it was starting to get dark. This a a stone hut built by the CCC. A real classic, it even has a stone fire place inside, like the shelters in the Smokies. Backdraft hiked with me in the PM, it was great having him during the long afternoon.

I hiked from the shelter to Thornton Gap. Got a shuttle from Stanimals Hostel to Waynesboro where my sister picked me up and drove to Charlottesville. Tomorrow, I'll fly back to Florida. I had to cut short my hike due to family concerns but I am very happy with my hike. Shenandoah National Park is great, the weather was clear & dry and the hikers very friendly. It was great hike. I'll be back to hike from Thornton Gap to Harper Ferry. Happy Trails to you.
